comment._content: I love the cheeky pose of the mom on the right...and I have a feeling the kid in the middle is a girl with her hair pulled back...my grandfather went to San Francisco from Belfast with his whole family when he was four, around 1891, and he helped his dad with their laundry wagon. The horses had a real hard time on the steep hills on the cobblestones, he said. If I can ever find a photo of them and their wagon, would you like me to share it with you?

comment.author: 75022648@N04
comment._content: My grandmother was Mary (Farrell) O'Malley. Her mother was Jane Farrell who married James Mannion. Mary Farrell's dad was Edward Farrell and his wife was Mary Coonaughton. They were from Williamstown Galway. If anyone may have any information on the family please email me at tmatn@aol.com

comment.author: 52257493@N00
comment._content: It's wonderful

comment.author: 98209876@N08
comment._content: Even the black doggies posed nicely for the photographer

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content:
I think this mystery deserves a fresh look as I'm sure with the right approach and a bit of luck we could identify who these people are, and where it was taken. I've certainly seen photos with fewer clues identified.

My instinct is to pursue the connection with the Farrell name as I would support the presumption that it is relatives who had emigrated. So, who was Mr J Farrell of New Ross? I can't find anyone from a quick look on Ancestry, but I'm not familiar with Irish records. On the other hand I can find quite a few Farrells who emigrated to the US in the latter half of the 19th century. Did one of them have a brother called John or James or Joseph or anything else beginning with a J who stayed in Wexford? Did they have two girls and then a boy in the very earliest years of the 1900s?  There's one very tentative candidate I can find from Wisconsin - does the architecture work for there?

As an aside, what was Poole doing creating this? Your records say that it is a glass negative, yet there are no strong signs I can make out that it is a copy of another image (if it is, it is of exceptional quality, though I would like to see a scan of the complete negative, or indeed the original). If it isn't an original, when might that have actually been taken?

comment.author: 47079330@N03
comment._content: A quick search of the 1911 census reveals that Mr J. FARRELL of Ballyknock, New Ross was most likely www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Kilkenny/Dysart... James FARRELL age 40 years, married to Johanna, 36 years old. Three children listed :- Mary Jane, Statia and Sarah. Two female servants living in the household.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture] Hi James, and thanks for taking a special interest in this one! What we have is definitely a glass plate negative...

And we do have other copies that Poole made of earlier images, or of scenes in "foreign parts".
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47079330@N03] Excellent, thank you very much!

comment.author: 47079330@N03
comment._content: Plus extra info... James FARRELL of Ballyknock, Kilkenny was a farmer. Perhaps a sibling emigrated who was also a farmer.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47079330@N03] Had a bit of an explore on Google Maps and I'm getting the same general area come up whether I search for Ballyknock in Co. Kilkenny or Ballyknock near New Ross in Co. Wexford. I think Ballyknock may be on/near the Kilkenny/Wexford border?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: Thanks both for picking up on this - it sounds like we might have our J Farrell. And more excitingly it does seem to link with my Wisconsin suggestion above. Let me piece together my research and post something in a minute. For once one of my hunches may prove to be right!

comment.author: 47079330@N03
comment._content: And I'll throw in a suggestion in the meantime. At the time of the 1911 census when James Farrell was 40 years old, he and his wife had only been married for 6 years, daughters ages 4, 3 and less. Given that he was that age before he married and a farmer I wonder if he could emigrated to the USA several years earlier (I cannot as yet find him on the 1901 census) , possibly married and had a family out there, things didn't work out etc and he returned to Ireland married and had a family. If the photo is a copy it was requested perhaps to remind himself of his time abroad? Just a thought.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: Hmmm, maybe my hunch wasn't correct. The Wisconsin connection was a Bridget Farrell (b1833) who married a Michael Ryan (b1822), so another Farrell/Ryan partnership. Both were born in Wexford, Michael actually in New Ross. They married in St Louis, Missouri in 1852. But I have yet to find any evidence that Bridget is related to James, even though there are some quite comprehensive family trees on Ancestry that I had hoped would help. I was especially looking for any siblings of Bridget who may have stayed in Ireland, especially if they had a child called James! I have found an email address though for someone who has researched Bridget's family so I've sent the link to them.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: Hold on, just as I was about to leave it, I've found that Bridget had a daughter called Johanna in 1862. In 1900 Johanna is living at Eau Galle Town, St. Croix, Wisconsin with "children Willie [possibly Nellie - see next entry] age 7, Agnes age 5, Sylvester age 3 and Evangelina age 1. Household Members: John B McGinley age 37, his wife Joan age 35" In 1905 she's still at Eau Galle, St Croix, Wisconsin, with "children Nellie age 12, Agnes age 10, Sylvester age 8, Evangeline age 6, Stasia age 3 and Ketherine age 1.; Household Members: Jno B McGinley age 42, his wife Johanna age 39" All of this is from trees.ancestry.co.uk/tree/19495798/person/810900612 What is strange is that there is no mention of a husband/father of the children, although in 1910 there's the rather curious entry "Household Members: John B McGinley age 48, his wife James (s/b Joanna) age 48". Had James left as EastMarple1 suggests? It seems not too great a leap of faith (though that is all it is) to suggest that the image could have been taken about 1901 and shows James and Johanna with Nellie, Agnes and Sylvester, and could that even be John McGinley on the carriage? EDIT: if James and Johanna were only married in 1905, where does this leave us? If the Johanna is one and the same then she had had three children in the US, possibly with another father given that he is not mentioned, but then came back to Ireland without them. Somehow I'm thinking it's not quite as simple as my hypothesis!

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: Where next? Shipping records for James Farrell? Local history people in Eau Galle? Trying to trace records for the various children?

comment.author: 47079330@N03
comment._content:
Going back to the 1911 census it looks like Johanna's maiden surname may have initially been added (first two letters only) then crossed out to be replaced with FARRELL. The two letters were "HO" 
Daughter Statia was really Anastasia. Believe Mary Jane was actually Mary Johanna and mistranscribed. Mary Johanna ties in with the civil registration of a birth in New Ross for applicable date.
